awd_titl_txt: ATD: Models of Spreading Dynamics in Multilayer Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will undertake a three-year project to study opinion and content spreading in multichannel communication networks. Many people rely on online sources for their news and information; and people spread diverse content on these interconnected media. However, the content on media varies in quality and trustworthiness, from high-quality and thoroughly-researched content to puff pieces and misinformation. Both the quality and the viewpoint of online content, which the PI will incorporate into novel mathematical models of opinion and content spreading, have an enormous influence on online discussions on issues such as economic and social policy and on interactions with others of differing views. This project will study the structure of multichannel communication networks; analyze new mathematical models on these networks to gain a thorough understanding of the mechanisms of content spread interacting with opinion shifts of users on these networks; and use this analysis to develop strategies to flag content in a way that is analogous to spam filters, thereby helping guide users to better navigate content on various forms of media. The results of this project will also inform and feed back directly into theory and applications of networks in many disciplines, such as by improving methodology for studying how the structure of networks influences processes (content spreading, transportation, flow of nutrients, and others) that occur on networks.  This project will support 2 graduate students each year.

The PI will undertake a three-year project to study opinion and content spreading in multichannel communication networks. This project has three components. First, using the new mathematical formalism of multilayer networks, the PI will analyze the structure of multichannel communication networks and develop network models of it in the form of multilayer random graphs. Second, the PI will generalize bounded-confidence models of opinion dynamics from monolayer networks to multilayer networks (this type of dynamical process has not been studied previously on multilayer networks, which one can use to encode networks with multiple types of edges or which consist of multiple subsystems), and the PI will systematically analyze the behavior of the these models through Monte Carlo simulations and regression analysis. Third, the PI will develop a model of interacting spreading of opinions (which are continuous-valued and can be in one or more dimensions) and content (which spreads through a discrete choice) by augmenting multilayer bounded-confidence models with media nodes that spread information of heterogeneous content qualities. Using this model, the PI will develop methodology to examine structural differences between the spreading properties of low-quality and high-quality content, thereby advancing the ability to filter disparate forms of content in networks. The results of this project will also inform and feed back directly into theory and applications of networks in many disciplines, such as by providing a principled method for determining the weights of interlayer edge in multilayer networks (a key open issue in applications of multilayer network analysis). The novel model of multilayer opinion dynamics will also influence the study of dynamical processes on networks more generally, advancing studies on novel phase transitions and bifurcations that arise from multilayer network architectures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Information, misinformation, and other content spreads in social networks. As people interact with each other and spread content in a social network, their opinions change. By using mathematical models, one can study how opinions change on networks in idealized scenarios. Insights into these mathematical models, which allow detailed analyses, give importance guidance about opinion dynamics and improve our understanding of how opinions change in real-life scenarios.

In this project, my team developed new mathematical models of opinion dynamics and analyzed their behavior. We focused especially on “bounded-confidence models” (BCMs), in which interacting individuals influence each other if and only if their opinions are sufficiently similar. My project had three key aims. In Aim 1, my team examined network structures, with the aim of improving understanding of how social-network structures affect dynamical processes (such as opinion dynamics) that occur on networks. In Aim 2, my team generalized existing opinion models in various ways, and we analyzed how these new models differ from existing models. In Aim 3, my team incorporated the effect of media into opinion models, analyzed the spread of content in opinion models, and formulated a mathematical condition to determine the onset of “infodemics” (i.e., information epidemics) in one model. We made the most progress on Aim 2, where we developed and studied the behavior of many new opinion models, but we also obtained a variety of useful results in the other two aims.

To illustrate where my team made the most progress (namely, Aim 2), I will briefly describe some of the new opinion models that my team developed. These models incorporate ideas from both social psychology and real-life experiences in idealized forms. Our results on our new opinion models include a mixture of mathematical results, supporting numerical simulations of opinion models, and data analysis of the results of computations. Our mathematical results include theorems that guarantee that opinions in a model converge to a steady state, which is important to ensure that a model behaves well when it is used for applications. Our computational results include characterizing when an opinion model yields a consensus state (in which there is one major group of opinions), a polarized state (in which there are two major opinion groups), and a fragmented state (in which there are three or more major opinion groups). Our data-analysis results include improvements in what to calculate (e.g., a notion of entropy) to successfully characterize the set of opinions in a network. Our new opinion models include both BCMs and other types of opinion models. Our new BCMs incorporate phenomena such as heterogeneous activity levels of individuals (e.g., some people post more frequently than others on social media), adaptive tolerances of others’ opinions (because past interactions between a pair of individuals inform subsequent interactions), media and stubborn individuals, and interactions between many individuals at once. Our new opinion models that take forms other than BCMs incorporate ideas like the time history of individual opinions, randomness in when interactions occur between individuals, distinct opinions for individuals and small groups, and other. My team also formulated a mathematical approach to solve an “inverse problem” to infer interaction rules between individuals if one possesses certain aggregated data measurements of their opinions (e.g., which can be obtained from a survey). This last result offers a way to proceed further in the challenging problem of validating opinion models using real-life data.

My project has resulted in 31 papers, with several additional papers in progress. The work on this project has appeared predominantly in journals in applied mathematics, physics, and network science. This project funded the training of several graduate students and undergraduate students in network analysis, dynamical processes on networks, opinion dynamics, mathematical modeling, scientific computation, and data analysis. It also supported the training in these topics of several additional graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral scholars who were funded by other sources. My project also supported the development of educational materials and outreach efforts. For example, our team published 5 papers in Frontiers for Young Minds, a journal with the goal of making research accessible to children of ages 8–15 years, which has allowed us to introduce ideas from network science and complex systems (specifically, mathematical modeling of opinion dynamics, finding shortest paths in networks, the so-called “waiting-time paradox”, topological data analysis, and mathematical modeling of disease spread) to teenagers and preteens. Additionally, I co-organized a Mathematical Research Community on “complex social systems” through the American Mathematical Society to develop a group of early-career researchers in this research area.
